description: From pre- +‎ occupy, after Middle French preoccuper, and its source, Latin praeoccupo, praeoccupare. Doublet of preoccupate, now obsolete.

verbs.description: preoccupy (third-person singular simple present preoccupies, present participle preoccupying, simple past and past participle preoccupied)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To distract; to draw attention elsewhere. [from 16th c.]
examples: The father tried to preoccupy the child with his keys.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To worry or concern (someone) so as to distract them.
examples: It always preoccupies me when he acts like this.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To occupy or take possession of beforehand. [16th–19th c.]
